key_insight: Injecting explicit world knowledge and lightweight reasoning into sequential recommender models converts sparse, ID-based item signals into rich semantic representations, enabling the model to capture beyond-log user interests and improve robustness under data sparsity.
problem_solved: Addresses brittle interest modeling caused by ID-only item representations and the inability of log-driven systems to perceive user preferences outside platform interaction histories.
method: Map ID-based items to semantic world knowledge (e.g., product text, attributes, knowledge graph nodes) to produce content-rich item embeddings.
Apply a reasoning module (retrieval + lightweight inference) to augment user interaction sequences with inferred, beyond-log interests and semantic relations.
Fuse the knowledge-augmented sequence into a sequential modeling backbone (e.g., Transformer/RNN) and train with objectives that encourage generalization and robustness under sparse logs.
impact: Provides a practical pattern to make recommender systems less brittle and more aware of real-world product semantics and latent user intent, improving cold-start handling and cross-platform generalization for practitioners.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: user click sequence → knowledge retrieval (text/KG) → reasoning/augmentation → sequential model → recommendations
Before vs. after bar chart: metrics (e.g., CTR/Recall) comparing ID-only baseline vs. knowledge-augmented model under low-data regimes
Knowledge graph / semantic embedding sketch: items linked to concepts/attributes showing how world knowledge enriches item representations
Icon set: cold-start (snowflake), world knowledge (globe/book), reasoning (brain/lightbulb), robustness (shield)
paper_title: ReaSeq: Unleashing World Knowledge via Reasoning for Sequential Modeling
paper_authors: Chuan Wang, Gaoming Yang, Han Wu, Jiakai Tang, Jiahao Yu
